statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Michael Jordan and the Washington Wizards extended the longest losing streak in Pat Riley's storied coaching career Friday night.
article.headline: Heat's futility streak reaches 11

images.name: Jordan, Michael 011130 team inline
images.caption: Michael Jordan had 22 points and seven rebounds.

article.linkText: Eleven and counting: Wiz beat wilted Heat
article.story:
MIAMI (AP) -- Michael Jordan caught the ball just inside the arc, looked directly into LaPhonso Ellis' eyes and asked, "You ready?" Ellis thought he was. But Jordan proved him wrong, hitting several long-range jumpers over the 6-foot-8 forward -- including one right after a little trash talking in the first quarter -- as the Washington Wizards extended the longest losing streak in Pat Riley's storied coaching career Friday night. Jordan had 22 points, seven rebounds and five assists as the Wizards beat Miami 84-75, handing the Heat their 11th consecutive loss. "I was trying to make him take tough shots, and he was," Ellis said. "He was hitting fadeaways from 20 feet. Against most people, that's great defense. But he's been knocking those shots down for some time." Jordan scored eight points in the decisive fourth quarter and led the team in scoring for the 13th time in 15 games. He finished 10-of-20 shooting. He hit four jump shots in the final period. The first one tied the game at 70, the next two came during an 8-0 run and the final one put the game out of reach. "Michael made some huge shots for us tonight," Wizards coach Doug Collins said. "I'm sure Pat Riley hates to see him because through the years he's made such big shots. He was simply awesome." Richard Hamilton added 19 points, and the Wizards ended an 11-game losing streak to Miami. In what has become routine, the Heat struggled to score down the stretch. Alonzo Mourning had just four points on 2-of-7 shooting, while Ellis led the team with 24 points. Washington packed its defense inside, giving point guards Anthony Carter and Rod Strickland open outside shots. They were a combined 8-of-30 shooting -- none of the shots from 3-point range -- and scored 18 points. "You just can't keep guarding and guarding and guarding and never get any sugar at the other end," Riley said. "It just deflates everything. The major problem is that we just can't score when it counts." Miami lost the first 17 games of its inaugural season in 1988, then dropped 13 in a row the following year. But this could be the low point since -- it certainly is for Riley, who never lost this many straight with the Lakers or the Knicks. "Is there anything I can do that I haven't done? I'll keep looking," Riley said. "I'll probably tweak the lineup as best I can and move in another direction." Coming off a 78-72 loss to the struggling Chicago Bulls on Thursday, the Heat looked like they might end the streak when they opened up a 13-point lead early in the third quarter. But Chris Whitney scored 10 points in the quarter -- including eight in a 11-0 run -- and helped the Wizards outscore Miami 23-17 in the third and tie it at 66 headed into the fourth. Jordan took over from there. "We really clamped down in the second half after having given away the momentum in the second quarter," he said. "We fought our way back into the game." Jordan was equally strong in the first quarter. He hit his first five shots in the first quarter and scored 12 points. He made four jumpers and then a no-look, back-to-the-basket, left-handed layup with several defenders around him. He was fouled on the shot, and missed the layup. His first miss from the floor came with 2:50 to play in the opening quarter. Jordan had the Wizards up eight early, but the Heat tied the score behind Ellis' 17 first-half points. Ellis was 7-of-9 shooting in the first half and 3-of-4 from 3-point range. The Heat led 49-43 at halftime, then led 56-43 in the third but were outscored 41-19 the rest of the way. "This is a very, very humbling experience," Mourning said. "We've got to continue to come back harder and try to make a difference in the next game. There's not too much more you can say."

Game notes
Jordan was 0-for-1 from 3-point range, dropping his season total to 2-for-18 from behind the arc. ... Miami's Chris Gatling was poked in the eye in the first half, but returned. ... The Heat used their 12th different starting lineup in 15 games. ... Former Wizards coach Leonard Hamilton was at the game.
